HTMLとは.title: What is HTML
HTMLとは.content:
# What is HTML

**HTML (HyperText Markup Language)** is a markup language for describing the structure of web pages.

## Role of HTML

1. **Content structuring**: Define structure such as headings, paragraphs, lists
2. **Creating links**: Implement hyperlinks between pages
3. **Embedding images and videos**: Display multimedia content
4. **Creating forms**: Accept user input

## Features of HTML

- **Enclose with tags**: Format `<tag>content</tag>`
- **Hierarchical structure**: Create structure by nesting elements
- **Attributes**: Can add additional information to tags
- **Case insensitive**: `<HTML>` and `<html>` are the same (lowercase recommended)

## Relationship between HTML, CSS, and JavaScript

```
HTML       → Structure (skeleton)
CSS        → Design (appearance)
JavaScript → Behavior (interaction)
```

HTML is the **foundation** technology for web pages.

HTML文書の各部分の説明.content:
# Each Part of HTML Document

## DOCTYPE Declaration

```html
<!DOCTYPE html>
```

- Declares that this is an HTML5 document
- Required for browsers to render correctly
- Must be written at the beginning of the document

## html Element

```html
<html lang="en">
```

- Root element of HTML document
- Specify language with `lang` attribute (Japanese is "ja", English is "en")

## head Element

Area for describing document meta information. Not displayed on the page.

```html
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
    <title>Page Title</title>
</head>
```

### Main Child Elements

- `<meta charset="UTF-8">`: Character encoding specification (UTF-8 recommended)
- `<meta name="viewport" ...>`: Mobile device settings
- `<title>`: Title displayed in browser tab
- `<link>`: Load external CSS files
- `<style>`: CSS description
- `<script>`: Load JavaScript files

## body Element

```html
<body>
    <!-- Write page content here -->
</body>
```

- Describe content displayed on the page
- Headings, paragraphs, images, links, etc.

画像フォーマットの選択.title: Choosing Image Format
画像フォーマットの選択.content: # Choosing Image Format ## JPEG (.jpg, .jpeg) **Features**: - Best for photos - High compression rate - No transparency support **Uses**: - Photos - Complex gradients - Background images **Advantages**: - Small file size - Can express many colors **Disadvantages**: - Cannot be transparent - Degrades when compressed ```html ``` ## PNG (.png) **Features**: - Transparency support - Lossless compression - Best for illustrations **Uses**: - Logos - Icons - Images requiring transparency - Screenshots **Advantages**: - Can be transparent - No degradation when compressed - Strong for sharp lines **Disadvantages**: - Large file size for photos ```html ``` ## GIF (.gif) **Features**: - Animation support - Up to 256 colors - Transparency support (1-bit) **Uses**: - Simple animations - Simple icons **Advantages**: - Can create animations - Small file size **Disadvantages**: - Limited colors (256) - Not suitable for photos ```html ``` ## SVG (.svg) **Features**: - Vector format - Looks good when enlarged - XML-based **Uses**: - Logos - Icons - Shapes - Graphs **Advantages**: - No degradation when scaled - Small file size - Can change colors with CSS **Disadvantages**: - Not suitable for complex images ```html ``` ## WebP (.webp) **Features**: - Next-generation format - Lighter than JPEG/PNG - Transparency/animation support **Uses**: - Photos - Illustrations - General use **Advantages**: - Small file size - Good quality **Disadvantages**: - Not supported in old browsers ```html ``` ## AVIF (.avif) **Features**: - Latest format - Even lighter than WebP **Uses**: - Latest websites **Advantages**: - Best compression rate **Disadvantages**: - Limited browser support ## Selection Guidelines ``` Photos → JPEG or WebP Logos/Icons → PNG or SVG Animations → GIF or WebP Transparency needed → PNG or WebP Scaling needed → SVG ```

form要素の属性.title: Form Element Attributes
form要素の属性.content:
# Form Element Attributes

## Basic Syntax

```html
<form action="destination URL" method="submission method">
    <!-- Form content -->
</form>
```

## Main Attributes

### action

Specifies the destination URL for form data

```html
<form action="/contact" method="POST">
    <!-- ... -->
</form>
```

- Specifies server-side endpoint
- If omitted, submits to current page

### method

Specifies data submission method

```html
<!-- GET method (default) -->
<form action="/search" method="GET">
    <input type="text" name="q">
    <button type="submit">Search</button>
</form>
<!-- URL: /search?q=search keyword -->

<!-- POST method -->
<form action="/login" method="POST">
    <input type="email" name="email">
    <input type="password" name="password">
    <button type="submit">Login</button>
</form>
```

**GET vs POST**:
- **GET**: Data appears in URL, bookmarkable, good for search forms
- **POST**: Not shown in URL, secure, good for login/registration

### name

Gives a name to the entire form (optional)

```html
<form name="contactForm" action="/submit" method="POST">
    <!-- ... -->
</form>
```

### autocomplete

Enable/disable autocomplete

```html
<!-- Enable autocomplete -->
<form autocomplete="on">

<!-- Disable autocomplete -->
<form autocomplete="off">
```

### novalidate

Disable HTML5 validation

```html
<form novalidate>
    <input type="email" required>
    <!-- Browser validation not performed -->
</form>
```

### enctype

Required for file uploads

```html
<form action="/upload" method="POST" enctype="multipart/form-data">
    <input type="file" name="document">
    <button type="submit">Upload</button>
</form>
```

**enctype types**:
- `application/x-www-form-urlencoded`: Default
- `multipart/form-data`: For file uploads
- `text/plain`: Text only (e.g., for email)

### target

Display destination for submission result

```html
<!-- Open in new tab -->
<form action="/submit" method="POST" target="_blank">

<!-- Open in iframe -->
<form action="/submit" method="POST" target="myIframe">
```

# What is Semantic HTML **Semantic HTML** is an approach that gives **meaning** to HTML tags. ## Why Semantic HTML is Important ### 1. Improved Accessibility Assistive technologies like screen readers can correctly understand page structure. ```html
Header
Navigation
Content
Header
Navigation
Content
``` ### 2. SEO Benefits Search engines can better understand page structure and content. ### 3. Code Readability Developers can immediately see the role of each part. ### 4. Maintainability Using meaningful tags makes it easier to modify later. ## div vs Semantic Elements ### Structure with div (Non-semantic) ```html
Site Name
Menu
Article
Sidebar
Footer
``` ### Structure with Semantic Elements ```html

Site Name

Menu
Article
Sidebar
Footer
``` ## Main Semantic Elements - `
`: Header (introduction of page or section) - `
`: Navigation - `
`: Main content - `
`: Independent content - `
`: Section (group of related content) - `
`: Supplementary information (sidebar, etc.) - `
`: Footer (end of page or section) ## When to Use div div is a generic container with **no meaning**. ```html
``` **Principle**: Use appropriate semantic elements if available, otherwise use div

アクセシビリティの重要性.title: Importance of Accessibility
アクセシビリティの重要性.content: # What is Web Accessibility **Web accessibility** means making websites usable by all users, regardless of disabilities. --- ## Why Accessibility is Important ### 1. Legal Obligation Many countries legally require web accessibility. - Japan: Act on the Elimination of Discrimination against Persons with Disabilities - USA: ADA (Americans with Disabilities Act) - EU: European Accessibility Act ### 2. Business Benefits - **Expanded user base**: Accessible to people with disabilities, elderly, and those with temporary disabilities - **SEO improvement**: Accessible sites are easier for search engines to understand - **Brand image improvement**: Evaluated as a company fulfilling social responsibility ### 3. Benefits All Users Improving accessibility helps **all users**, not just those with disabilities. - **Elderly**: Declining vision/hearing - **Temporary disabilities**: One hand unavailable due to injury, screen hard to see in bright places - **Situational constraints**: Noisy environment, slow network, old devices --- ## Types of Disabilities and Responses ### 1. Visual Impairment **Symptoms**: - Total blindness (cannot see at all) - Low vision (partially visible) - Color blindness (difficulty distinguishing colors) **Response**: - Screen reader support - Appropriate contrast ratio - Information not dependent on color alone ```html ``` ### 2. Hearing Impairment **Symptoms**: - Total deafness (cannot hear at all) - Hard of hearing (partially audible) **Response**: - Provide subtitles for videos - Transcribe audio information - Visual feedback ```html ``` ### 3. Motor Impairment **Symptoms**: - Cannot use mouse - Difficulty with fine operations **Response**: - Keyboard operation support - Large click areas - Voice input support ```html ``` ### 4. Cognitive Impairment **Symptoms**: - Difficulty understanding complex content - Difficulty maintaining concentration **Response**: - Simple language - Clear navigation - Consistent design --- ## WCAG (Web Content Accessibility Guidelines) **WCAG** is the international standard for web accessibility. ### 4 Principles (POUR) 1. **Perceivable** - Information and UI components are presented in ways users can perceive 2. **Operable** - UI components and navigation are operable 3. **Understandable** - Information and UI operation are understandable 4. **Robust** - Content can be interpreted by various user agents, including assistive technologies ### Conformance Levels - **Level A**: Minimum requirements - **Level AA**: Moderate requirements (recommended) - **Level AAA**: Highest level requirements --- ## Basic Accessibility Checklist ### ✅ Images - [ ] Set `alt` attribute for all images - [ ] Use `alt=""` (empty) for decorative images - [ ] Don't provide important information only in images ```html ``` ### ✅ Links and Buttons - [ ] Link text is clear in purpose - [ ] Avoid links that only say "here" - [ ] Use `

レスポンシブ画像の必要性.title: Need for Responsive Images
レスポンシブ画像の必要性.content: # What are Responsive Images **Responsive images** are a technology that displays optimal images according to device screen size and resolution. --- ## Why Responsive Images are Needed ### 1. Performance Improvement No need to download huge images on smartphones. - **Bad example**: Loading 4K monitor images (5MB) on smartphones too - **Good example**: Delivering lightweight version (300KB) to smartphones ### 2. Improved User Experience - Save mobile users' data usage - Reduced loading time - Reduced battery consumption ### 3. Support for Retina/High-Resolution Displays - Normal 1x images appear blurry on high-resolution displays - Providing 2x, 3x images for sharp display --- ## 3 Use Cases for Responsive Images ### 1. Resolution Switching **Purpose**: Provide different sizes of the same image ```html ``` ### 2. Art Direction **Purpose**: Display different images (cropped or layout changed) according to device ```html ``` ### 3. Format Switching **Purpose**: Support latest formats like WebP while providing fallback ```html ``` --- ## Traditional Problems ### ❌ Fixed Size Images ```html ``` **Problems**: - Downloading 1200px images on smartphones too (wasteful) - Large images unnecessary for small screen display - Increased data usage and load time ### ❌ Resizing with CSS Only ```html ``` **Problems**: - Display size becomes smaller but download size doesn't change - Downloading unnecessarily large images --- ## Solution: srcset and sizes ### srcset Attribute Provides browser with multiple image candidates. ```html ``` **Explanation**: - `400w`, `800w`, `1200w` are actual image widths (pixels) - `w` stands for "width" - Browser automatically selects optimal image ### sizes Attribute Tells browser the width at which image will be displayed. ```html ``` **Explanation**: - `(max-width: 600px) 100vw`: Image is 100vw (full screen width) when screen width is 600px or less - `50vw`: Otherwise image is 50vw (half screen width) --- ## Retina Support (High-Resolution Displays) ### x Notation Specify images with device pixel ratio (DPR). ```html ``` **Explanation**: - `1x`: Standard display - `2x`: Retina, high-resolution displays (iPhone, etc.) - `3x`: Ultra-high resolution displays (iPhone Pro Max, etc.) --- ## Summary | Method | Purpose | |--------|---------| | `srcset + sizes` | Provide different sizes of same image | | `` | Display different images according to device | | `x notation` | Retina support (high-resolution displays) | **Best Practices**: 1. Always specify `src` attribute (fallback) 2. Prepare multiple sizes (minimum 3: small, medium, large) 3. Prioritize latest formats like WebP 4. Always set `alt` attribute

picture要素とsrcset.title: picture Element and srcset
picture要素とsrcset.content:
Responsive Image Implementation Examples

1. srcset - Resolution Switching

Browser automatically selects optimal image according to screen size.

Code Example 
<img
    src="image-800w.jpg"
    srcset="
        image-400w.jpg 400w,
        image-800w.jpg 800w,
        image-1200w.jpg 1200w
    "
    sizes="(max-width: 600px) 400px, (max-width: 1000px) 800px, 1200px"
    alt="Image"
>

2. Retina Support (x notation)

Supports high-resolution displays.

Code Example 
<img
    src="logo-1x.png"
    srcset="
        logo-1x.png 1x,
        logo-2x.png 2x,
        logo-3x.png 3x
    "
    alt="Logo"
    width="200"
>

3. picture Element - Art Direction

Displays different images (cropped or layout) according to device.

Code Example 
<picture>
    <source media="(max-width: 600px)" srcset="image-mobile.jpg">
    <source media="(max-width: 1000px)" srcset="image-tablet.jpg">
    <img src="image-desktop.jpg" alt="Image">
</picture>

4. Format Switching (WebP Support)

Supports latest formats while providing fallback for old browsers.

Code Example 
<picture>
    <source srcset="image.avif" type="image/avif">
    <source srcset="image.webp" type="image/webp">
    <img src="image.jpg" alt="Image">
</picture>

5. Combined Example (Format + Responsive + Retina)

Example combining format switching, resolution switching, and Retina support.

Code Example 
<picture>
    <!-- WebP (mobile, Retina) -->
    <source
        media="(max-width: 600px)"
        srcset="
            image-400w.webp 1x,
            image-800w.webp 2x
        "
        type="image/webp"
    >
    <!-- WebP (desktop, Retina) -->
    <source
        srcset="
            image-800w.webp 1x,
            image-1600w.webp 2x
        "
        type="image/webp"
    >
    <!-- JPEG (fallback) -->
    <img src="image-800w.jpg" alt="Image">
</picture>

6. Practical Example: E-commerce Product Image

Summary

Method Purpose Notation
srcset (w notation) Image switching according to screen size image.jpg 800w
srcset (x notation) Retina support image.jpg 2x
<picture> Art direction, format switching <source> and <img>
sizes Specify image display width (max-width: 600px) 100vw

Canvas と SVG の違い.title: Difference between Canvas and SVG
Canvas と SVG の違い.content:
# Difference between Canvas and SVG

There are two methods for drawing graphics in HTML: **Canvas** and **SVG**.

---

## Canvas

**Canvas** is a **bitmap-based** drawing area for drawing shapes and graphics with JavaScript.

### Features

- **Bitmap (Raster)**: Draws pixel by pixel
- **Controlled with JavaScript**: Draws with code, doesn't create HTML elements
- **Fast**: Advantageous when drawing many elements
- **Dynamic**: Suitable for animations and games

### Usage Example

```html
<canvas id="myCanvas" width="400" height="200"></canvas>

<script>
const canvas = document.getElementById('myCanvas');
const ctx = canvas.getContext('2d');

// Draw rectangle
ctx.fillStyle = '#FF0000';
ctx.fillRect(50, 50, 150, 100);

// Draw circle
ctx.beginPath();
ctx.arc(300, 100, 50, 0, 2 * Math.PI);
ctx.fillStyle = '#0000FF';
ctx.fill();
</script>
```

---

## SVG (Scalable Vector Graphics)

**SVG** is **vector-based** graphics described in XML format.

### Features

- **Vector**: Shapes expressed with formulas (no degradation when enlarged)
- **DOM Elements**: Can be treated as part of HTML
- **Controllable with CSS and JavaScript**: Easy styling and event handling
- **Accessible**: Can be read as text

### Usage Example

```html
<svg width="400" height="200">
    <!-- Rectangle -->
    <rect x="50" y="50" width="150" height="100" fill="#FF0000" />

    <!-- Circle -->
    <circle cx="300" cy="100" r="50" fill="#0000FF" />

    <!-- Text -->
    <text x="200" y="180" font-size="20" text-anchor="middle">SVG Text</text>
</svg>
```

---

## Canvas vs SVG Comparison Table

| Feature | Canvas | SVG |
|---------|--------|-----|
| **Format** | Bitmap (Raster) | Vector |
| **Drawing Method** | Draw with JavaScript | XML markup |
| **DOM** | Only single `<canvas>` element | Each shape is a DOM element |
| **Scaling** | Blurry (pixel-based) | No degradation (vector) |
| **Events** | Only on entire Canvas | Can be set individually on each shape |
| **Performance** | Fast with many elements | Fast with few elements |
| **Suitable Uses** | Games, animations, mass drawing | Icons, charts, few shapes |
| **Accessibility** | Low | High (can be treated as text) |

---

## When to Use Each

### Use Canvas When

- **Game Development**: Drawing many elements in real-time
- **Data Visualization**: Plotting tens of thousands of points
- **Image Editing**: Pixel-level operations needed
- **Animations**: High-speed drawing at 60fps

### Use SVG When

- **Icons**: No degradation when enlarged
- **Logos**: Want to manage as vector
- **Interactive Graphics**: Clickable shapes
- **Few Shapes**: DOM manipulation is convenient

---

## Practical Examples

### Animation with Canvas

```javascript
const canvas = document.getElementById('myCanvas');
const ctx = canvas.getContext('2d');

let x = 0;
function animate() {
    ctx.clearRect(0, 0, canvas.width, canvas.height);
    ctx.fillRect(x, 50, 50, 50);
    x += 2;
    if (x > canvas.width) x = 0;
    requestAnimationFrame(animate);
}
animate();
```

### Interactive Shapes with SVG

```html
<svg width="200" height="200">
    <circle
        cx="100"
        cy="100"
        r="50"
        fill="blue"
        onclick="this.setAttribute('fill', 'red')"
        style="cursor: pointer;"
    />
</svg>
```

---

## Summary

- **Canvas**: Draw with JavaScript, fast, suitable for many elements
- **SVG**: XML format, no degradation when enlarged, suitable for few shapes
- **Selection Criteria**: Judge based on use case and performance requirements

# Basics of Responsive Design **Responsive design** is a web design approach that provides optimal layouts according to device screen size. --- ## viewport Meta Tag The foundation of responsive design is **viewport** configuration. ```html Responsive Site ``` ### viewport Attributes - `width=device-width`: Match device screen width - `initial-scale=1.0`: Set initial zoom to 1 **Without this setting**, PC layout will be displayed on smartphones too. --- ## Mobile-First Approach **Mobile-first** is an approach where you first create smartphone design, then expand for desktop. ### Why Mobile-First 1. **Many mobile users**: Over 50% of web traffic 2. **Forces simplicity**: Display only what's truly needed on small screens 3. **Performance**: Start with lightweight mobile version ### Implementation Example ```html Mobile-First

Responsive Content

Layout changes according to screen size.

``` --- ## Summary - Set **viewport** to correctly recognize device screen width - Use **mobile-first** to create smartphone design first - Apply styles according to screen size with **media queries** - Keep HTML itself simple, control layout with CSS

# Comprehensive Assignment ①: Portfolio Site Creation

Create a **portfolio site** or **blog site** using the HTML knowledge learned so far.

---

## Required Requirements

### 1. Semantic HTML

- Use `<header>`, `<nav>`, `<main>`, `<article>`, `<section>`, `<aside>`, `<footer>` appropriately
- Use heading tags (h1～h6) hierarchically

### 2. Forms

- Implement contact form or comment form
- Appropriate validation (required, pattern, minlength, etc.)

### 3. Multimedia

- Images (responsive support)
- Include video or audio if possible

### 4. Accessibility

- alt attribute for all images
- label elements for forms
- Appropriate ARIA attributes (as needed)

### 5. Responsive Design

- viewport configuration
- Support for mobile, tablet, desktop

---

## Recommended Page Structure

### For Portfolio Site

1. **Top Page (index.html)**
   - Self-introduction
   - Skills list
   - Links to portfolio (works)

2. **Work Details Page (works.html)**
   - Project description
   - Technologies used
   - Screenshots

3. **Contact Page (contact.html)**
   - Form

### For Blog Site

1. **Top Page (index.html)**
   - Article list

2. **Article Details Page (article.html)**
   - Article body
   - Publication date, author information

3. **About Page (about.html)**
   - Blog description
   - Author profile

---

## Checklist

### HTML Structure

- [ ] DOCTYPE declaration exists
- [ ] lang attribute set (`<html lang="en">`)
- [ ] charset configuration (UTF-8)
- [ ] viewport configuration
- [ ] Appropriate title element

### Semantic

- [ ] Use semantic elements appropriately
- [ ] Heading hierarchy is correct
- [ ] Use lists appropriately (ul, ol, dl)

### Accessibility

- [ ] alt attribute for all images
- [ ] label elements for forms
- [ ] Sufficient contrast ratio
- [ ] Keyboard operable

### Validation

- [ ] No errors in W3C Validator
- [ ] HTML syntax is correct

---

## Deliverables

1. **HTML Files** (multiple allowed)
2. **README File**
   - Site overview
   - Technologies used
   - Points of effort

---

- Understanding of semantic HTML

最終チェックリストとSEO基礎.content: # Final Checklist and SEO Basics Final confirmation items before publishing the project. --- ## 1. HTML Validation ### W3C Markup Validation Service https://validator.w3.org/ **How to Use**: 1. Access the site 2. Upload HTML file or enter URL 3. Check errors and warnings 4. Fix all issues ### Common Errors - Missing closing tags - Missing quotes in attribute values - Nesting errors - Use of deprecated elements --- ## 2. Accessibility Check ### Lighthouse (Chrome DevTools) 1. Open Chrome DevTools (F12) 2. Select Lighthouse tab 3. Check "Accessibility" 4. Click "Generate report" ### Check Items - [ ] alt attribute for all images - [ ] label elements for forms - [ ] Color contrast ratio (4.5:1 or higher) - [ ] Heading hierarchy - [ ] Keyboard operable - [ ] Appropriate use of ARIA roles and attributes --- ## 3. SEO Basics ### Required Meta Tags ```html My Portfolio | Web Developer ``` ### SEO Checklist - [ ] `` tag is appropriate (55 characters or less, unique per page) - [ ] `description` meta tag is appropriate (155 characters or less) - [ ] Use heading tags (h1～h6) hierarchically - [ ] Set `alt` attribute for all images - [ ] Internal links are appropriate - [ ] URLs are clear - [ ] Page load speed is fast --- ## 4. Performance Optimization ### Image Optimization - [ ] Appropriate image format (WebP recommended) - [ ] Image size optimization (don't make unnecessarily large) - [ ] Use responsive images (srcset, picture) - [ ] Lazy loading (loading="lazy") ```html <img src="image.jpg" alt="Description" loading="lazy"> ``` ### HTML Optimization - [ ] Remove unnecessary whitespace and comments - [ ] Externalize CSS and JavaScript - [ ] Remove unnecessary tags --- ## 5. Final Presentation Preparation ### Presentation Content 1. **Site Overview** (1 minute) - What was created - Target audience 2. **Technical Explanation** (2 minutes) - HTML elements used - Points of effort - Challenges faced 3. **Demonstration** (2 minutes) - Show actual operation - Confirm responsive support 4. **Q&A** (1 minute) ### Documentation Creation **README.md** ```markdown # Project Name ## Overview This site is... ## Technologies Used - HTML5 - Semantic elements (header, nav, main, article, section, footer) - Responsive images (picture, srcset) - Form validation ## Points of Effort 1. Thorough semantic HTML 2. Accessibility consideration (WAI-ARIA usage) 3. Responsive support (mobile-first) ## Challenges Faced ... ## Future Improvements ... ``` --- ## Summary - **Validation**: Zero HTML syntax errors - **Accessibility**: Aim for Lighthouse score of 90+ - **SEO**: Set title, description meta tags appropriately - **Performance**: Image optimization, lazy loading - **Presentation**: Prepare to confidently explain your work **Congratulations! You've completed 15 weeks of HTML learning!**
